title: Making Renewable, Infinitely Recyclable Plastics Using Bacteria – Berkeley Lab News Center - Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (.gov)
summary: Researchers engineered E. coli to turn sugar from plants into biorenewable plastics (PDKs) that are efficiently recyclable and have expanded applications in the auto industry and more.
green_innovation: TRUE, This is a green innovation as it describes the development of a biorenewable plastic that reduces the use of polluting petrochemicals and promotes recycling.
business_innovation: FALSE, This is not a business innovation as it focuses on the development of a green product rather than a new business process.
green_product: TRUE, The article discusses the development of biorenewable plastics that significantly reduce environmental impact throughout their life cycle, meeting the criteria of a green product.
green_process: TRUE, The article describes the development of a method in manufacturing (using engineered microbes) that minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability through the production of biorenewable plastics, making it a green process.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 325211 (Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing), 325199 (All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing), 541710 (Biotechnology Research and Development), 541690 (Other Scientific and Technical Consulting Services)
greenwashing: FALSE, This is not greenwashing as the article discusses genuine advancements in developing biorenewable plastics and does not involve misleading environmental claims.
